--- title: Lecture 01a -- Welcome subtitle: ENVX2001 Applied Statistical Methods date: last-modified date-format: "MMM YYYY" author: - name: "Januar Harianto" email: "januar.harianto@sydney.edu.au" orcid: "0000-0001-5678-9012" affiliation: Lecturer, SOLES attributes: corresponding: true format: ochre-revealjs: default ochre-typst: fig-format: png --- # This is ENVX2001 ## Staff ::: {layout-ncol=4 style="text-align:center;"} ![A. Prof Aaron Greenville
Unit Coordinator
Weeks 4-6](images/aaron.tiff){height=300} ![Dr Liana Pozza
Lecturer
Weeks 7-9](images/liana.jpeg){height=300} ![Dr Januar Harianto
Lecturer
Weeks 1-3](images/januar.jpeg){height=300} ![Prof Mathew Crowther
Professor
Weeks 9-11](images/matcrowther.jpeg){height=300} ::: # Your statistical journey ## Does migration come at a cost? In a partially migratory elk population in Alberta, Canada, researchers compared calf birth weights between resident and migrant herds. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true"} elk <- read.csv("data/elk_calf_clean.csv") elk$mig_status <- factor(elk$mig_status, levels = c("Resident", "Eastern"), labels = c("Resident", "Migrant") ) ggplot(elk, aes(x = mig_status, y = birth_wt, fill = mig_status)) + geom_boxplot(show.legend = FALSE) + scale_fill_viridis_d(end = 0.9) + labs(x = NULL, y = "Birth weight (kg)") + theme_minimal(base_size = 18) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lecture-01a_files/figure-typst/elk-birthweight-1.png) ::: ::: *You have already learnt to compare groups like this with **t-tests** (Weeks 1--3).* ## Can dogs smell human stress? Eighteen pet dogs were exposed to odours from humans who were either relaxed or stressed. Researchers then measured how long each dog took to approach food bowls, looking for signs of anxiety. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true"} dogs <- read.csv("data/dog_odour_clean.csv") dogs$treatment <- factor(dogs$treatment, levels = c("Baseline", "Relaxed", "Stressed") ) dog_means <- aggregate(latency ~ dog_id + treatment, data = dogs, FUN = mean) ggplot(dog_means, aes(x = treatment, y = latency, colour = treatment)) + geom_jitter(width = 0.2, size = 3, alpha = 0.6) + stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "crossbar", width = 0.5, linewidth = 0.8, colour = "black") + scale_colour_viridis_d(end = 0.9) + labs(x = "Odour treatment", y = "Mean latency (s)") + theme_minimal(base_size = 18) + theme(legend.position = "none") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lecture-01a_files/figure-typst/dog-odour-1.png) ::: ::: What if there are more than 2 groups to compare? We use **ANOVA** (Weeks 3--6). ## How big is that penguin? Heavier penguins tend to have longer flippers -- but how strong is that relationship? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true"} penguins <- palmerpenguins::penguins ggplot(penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm, y = body_mass_g)) + geom_point(aes(colour = species), alpha = 0.6) + geom_smooth(method = "lm") + scale_colour_viridis_d(end = 0.9) + labs(x = "Flipper length (mm)", y = "Body mass (g)") + theme_minimal(base_size = 18) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lecture-01a_files/figure-typst/penguin-regression-1.png) ::: ::: We can model this relationship with **regression**, but how do we validate this against other models? You will learn to do this with **model selection** (Weeks 7--9). ## Darwin's finches: evolution you can measure Peter and Rosemary Grant spent 40 years measuring beak morphology in GalÃ¡pagos finches, documenting natural selection in real time. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true"} finches <- read.csv("data/darwin_finches_clean.csv") ggplot(finches, aes(x = beak_length, y = beak_depth, colour = species)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.5) + stat_ellipse(linewidth = 1) + scale_colour_viridis_d(end = 0.9) + labs(x = "Beak length (mm)", y = "Beak depth (mm)", colour = "Species") + theme_minimal(base_size = 18) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Lecture-01a_files/figure-typst/darwin-finches-1.png) ::: ::: Sometimes, patterns jump out to us in complex datasets. You will learn to find patterns like these with **multivariate methods** (Weeks 10--12). # Housekeeping ## Lectures Wednesdays 10am - 12pm, Chemistry Lecture Theatre 3 (CLT03) ![Copyright The University of Sydney](images/chemlt3.jpeg) ## Labs Labs are held at the **South Eveleigh Precinct** ![Credit: Michael Wheatland](images/biomedical.jpg) ## Directions from Carslaw [If the map does not load, click here](https://maps.app.goo.gl/vs6aXA6YY4cL98Po7) ## Transport options ### Buses [Courtesy buses][buses] are available from **Fisher Library** to **Redfern Station**. You must then walk to the precint (10 minutes). ### Driving Free parking is available around Henderson Road, but it is extremely crowded. We do *not* recommend driving to the precinct. ### Walking Walking to the South Eveleigh Precinct takes about 20 minutes from Carslaw. You can save approximately 5 minutes by using Redfern station's community access gates. # Expectations ## Attendance ### Lectures are compulsory, but not a hurdle - You are expected to attend 80% of lectures, and attendance is recorded via Ed Discussion Boards - Attendance is **not** a hurdle. We use attendance data to determine if students are engaging with the course ### Labs are compulsory with 80% minimum attendance - Labs are the heart of this unit. No exceptions except through special consideration - We will not record your attendance if you are not present for more than 50% of the lab session (we round things up) ## Assessments Check [Unit Outline](https://www.sydney.edu.au/units/ENVX2001/2026-S1C-ND-CC) | Week | Assessment | Weight | Type | |------|-------------------------------------------|---------|------------| | 3 | Early Feedback Task | 1% | Individual | | 5 | Project 1: Describing data | 10% | Individual | | 10 | Project 2: Analysing experimental data | 20% | Individual | | 13 | Project 3: Presentation (multivariate) | 20% | Group | | - | Quizzes (weekly, multiple due dates) | 4% | Individual | | - | Exam (2 hours, MCQs + Short Answers) | 45% | Individual | # Doing well ## Put in the hours - This is a **6 credit point** unit, which means that you are expected to spend **120 -- 150 hours** in total, including exam prep time (~10 h per week)! - **Practice makes perfect**. Tutorials and Labs help you apply the concepts you learn in lectures -- complete all the exercises, and practice with the bonus questions provided. ![](images/adventuretime.gif){fig-align="center" height=350} ## Ask questions Don't be afraid to seek help. We are happy when students show genuine interest to learn and will do our best to support you. Here are some ways to ask questions: - [**Ed Discussion**][edsite] is the *best* place to ask questions. We are way more responsive on **Ed** than on email. - **Drop-in sessions** are available. Check Ed Discussion for times and links. # Learning outcomes ## By the end of this course, we want you to be able to: - **LO1** demonstrate proficiency in designing sample schemes and analysing data from them **using R**. - **LO2** describe and identify the basic features of an **experimental design**: replicate, treatment structure and blocking structure. - **LO3** demonstrate proficiency in the use or the statistical programming language **R** to apply an ANOVA and fit regression models to experimental data. - **LO4** demonstrate proficiency in the use or the statistical programming language **R** to use multivariate methods to find patterns in data. - **LO5** interpret the output and understand conceptually how its derived of a regression, ANOVA and multivariate analysis that have been calculated by R. - **LO6** write statistical and modelling results as part of a scientific report. - **LO7** appraise the validity of statistical analyses used publications. # Questions? This presentation is based on the [SOLES Quarto reveal.js template](https://github.com/usyd-soles-edu/soles-revealjs) and is licensed under a [Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License][cc-by] ## Take a break We will resume the second half of the lecture in 10 minutes. Come on down if you have questions! [clt01]: https://venueweb.sydney.edu.au/F11.01.145 [clt03]: https://venueweb.sydney.edu.au/F11.02.238 [cc-by]: http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ [buses]: https://www.sydney.edu.au/about-us/campuses/getting-to-campus/campus-bus-timetables.html [edsite]:https://edstem.org/au/dashboard
